Scott Anderson
Web Designer
About Blog Work
Mobile App Design
Time Frame: 2.5 days
(See the project on GitHub or view it live)
Technology Used

Illustrator, Invision, Git.

Foundation

My wife and I love to play recreational kickball. We have amazing, fun memories from our time playing and made great friends along the way.

However, communication between the team members was lackluster at best. People were always confused about when the games were, where they were being played, and what the roster was going to be that night. A great tool for getting this information easily communicated between people would be a mobile app.

Research

Before starting anything else, I looked at some of my favorite mobile apps to see what they do well and not so well. This was to gain some inspiration and momentum before starting my design.

I also created some user stories, to get an idea of what the team members would want to know when logging on to the app.

I then went to the whiteboard, and wrote out what pieces of team and game information people would most likely want to know. I decided to draw up a user flow with these elements, so that I could start thinking about the map of the app.

Design

To aid me in the design of the app, I created a couple of stile tiles. this was my time for exploring such elements as colors, fonts, and themes.

I decided on following the stile guide which had a red color theme and a more serious, "gametime" tone. The tile with the orange and black felt too Halloween and kiddish at the same time.

Mockups and Icons

Most of my time during this project was spent creating mockups in Illustrator for each page of the app. Pages also needed to have a "sidebar" element inluded as well, which would be needed to show the functionality of the menu icon. I then uploaded the individual mockups into Invision.

The dashboard page needed icons, which I created as well in Illustrator.

Challenges Faced

Invision can be particular sometimes, requiring the mockup files to be a certain size to achieve the desired look I was after. Therefore I spent a lot of time going back and forth bewteen Invision and Illustrator until the sizes were correctly displayed in the prototype.

Also, in my original "finished" project I was never satisifed with the outcome. I later realized that a dashboard page of the app was missing. And so I went back and added the dashboard "home" screen to the project.
